Output: The machine learning algorithm used in the DMHI system for the classification of Tetrastigma hemsleyanum (T. hemsleyanum) was a support vector machine (SVM) model.

instruction: Can the dual-mode microscopic hyperspectral imager (DMHI) system combined with a machine learning algorithm be considered superior to traditional methods for the classification of origins and varieties of Tetrastigma hemsleyanum (T. hemsleyanum)?
Output: Yes, the dual-mode microscopic hyperspectral imager (DMHI) system combined with a machine learning algorithm can be considered superior to traditional methods for the classification of origins and varieties of Tetrastigma hemsleyanum (T. hemsleyanum). The DMHI system offers excellent performance with high spatial and spectral resolutions, allowing for detailed imaging and analysis of the plant samples. By switching between reflection imaging and fluorescence detection modes, the DMHI system captures hyperspectral datasets that provide comprehensive information about the samples. The datasets are then analyzed using principal component analysis (PCA) for dimensional reduction and a support vector machine (SVM) model for classification. The results of the classification experiments show high accuracy in distinguishing the origins and varieties of T. hemsleyanum in both reflection and fluorescence modes. When the datasets from both modes are combined, the trained model achieves excellent predictions with a high accuracy rate. This demonstrates the superiority of the DMHI system combined with machine learning in non-invasive detection and rapid quality assessment of medicinal herbs like T. hemsleyanum.
